pages.text: Coeloptychium comes from the Cretaceous, with fossils found across the globe. They are small lychniscosid glass sponges, growing up to 40 cm in height and with bulbs/caps 30 cm wide. Coeloptychium is a unique genus, in the fact that they have a rather mushroom-like appearance, with holdfasts, a stalk, and even a cap or bulb on top. They would vanish at the end of the Cretaceous period, although other mushroom-like lychniscosids would continue right up until the present day.
The generic name derives from the Greek word 'coelo', to mean 'cavity'; and 'ptycho', to mean 'fold'.
